Award.AwardTitle: Optical surface and defect states in light-induced photonic structures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Surface and defect states exist in a variety of systems that obey linear and nonlinear equations. In this RUI research project, new concepts and fundamental issues of wave propagation along surfaces and defects will be explored both experimentally and theoretically. The specific areas of investigation will include defect modes, defect-soliton interactions, nonlinear surface solitons, and Tamm- and Shockley-like surface states in biperiodic superlattice structures. Recently it has been suggested that the small refractive index variation induced as periodic arrays of evanescently coupled waveguides can be used for excitation of surface and defect states, but experimental demonstration in a two-dimensional configuration has been hampered by fabrication of such periodic structures with desired surfaces and defects. This project will be carried out in an optical setting of reconfigurable periodic structure using optically-induced photonic waveguide structures.

The research will have direct impact on other areas of sciences, ranging from solid state physics to photonic crystals, and from hydrodynamics to atomic physics such as Bose-Einstein condensates trapped in periodic potentials. A major emphasis of this project is placed on mentoring undergraduate students, particularly those from the ethnically diverse San Francisco Bay Area population. A strong educational component of this work is that the research project will be used as a form of teaching as well as discovery, and the students will be actively involved in learning research methods and in sharing discoveries and interpretations. Thus, the broader impacts of this project lie in the integration of research and education through training of students in a fundamentally and technologically important area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is a RUI research project in which undergraduate and Master-level graduate students have actively participated. The research work has been focused on the study of fundamental issues associated with wave propagation along surfaces and defects in optically-induced photonic structures. Since surface and defect states exist in a variety of linear and nonlinear systems, results from this project performed in an optical setting of reconfigurable periodic structures might have direct impact on other areas of sciences, ranging from solid state physics to hydrodynamics and matter waves.

The specific areas of investigation include linear and nonlinear defect modes, linear and nonlinear Tamm and Shockley-like surface states, and image transmission through linear and nonlinear photonic lattices. Major research findings from this NSF-funded project include the first demonstration of optical Shockley-like surface states in optically induced photonic superlattices, bandgap guidance of optical vortex modes by photonic defects, controlled Bragg reflection in ionic-type photonic lattices, image transmission based on CDT (coherent destructive tunneling) in 3D lattices and nonlinear gap solitons, and nonlinear beam deflection in photonic lattices with negative defects. These studies will advance the knowledge in several interdisciplinary areas.


A major emphasis of this project has been placed on mentoring students, particularly those from the ethnically diverse San Francisco Bay Area who are working in rapidly advancing STEM fields. The broader impacts of this project lie in the integration of research and education through training of students in a fundamentally and technologically important area. During the last three years funded by through this RUI award, about a dozen students involved in learning basic skills in optics and photonics, performing experiments, and preparing manuscripts and conference presentations. Many students not only published papers in leading journals, but also found that the training they received through this project was very helpful for reshaping their career goals. Such success would not have been possible without the NSF support.
